Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Pain Management in Minimally Invasive Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of pain management strategies in MICS.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were undergoing MICS and were recruited from a single cardiac surgery center.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received thoracic epidural analgesia (TEA), while the control group received thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB).

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of pain management strategies in MICS.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative pain measured on a visual analog scale (VAS) over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the TEA group and 100 to the TPVB group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the TEA group and 97 in the TPVB group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean VAS score was significantly lower in the TEA group (mean difference = 1.5, 95% CI 0.8 to 2.2; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 5% of the TEA group and 3% of the TPVB group, with no severe complications reported.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institute of Health.
